data.title: is_visible() possible bug?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1.2 stable

For example, look at this hierarchy:

ScrollContainer
--HBoxContainer
    --Button1
    --Button2
    --Button3
    --Button4
    --Button5
    --Button6

Let's say all the buttons are 100x20.

ScrollContainer's max width is 200

And only Button1 and Button2 are visible. You need to scroll to see 3,4,5,6. Which is normal :D

Except If you call `is_visible()` on all the buttons. They all will return true.

Shouldn't only Button1 and Button2 return true? (as the rest are not visible unless you scroll)

data.title: After close script:  next open script not relevant to the history hierarchy
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Xubuntu 16.04.2 LTS x64, Godot version: 2.1 d8ae244, master

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When open a multiple scripts and we close a some script (Ctrl+W), in some case a next open script not relevant to the history hierarchy.

**Steps to reproduce:**
If "**highlight current script**" enabled and we try some...
Open files in this sequence:
1.gd -> 2.gd -> 3.gd -> 1.gd -> 3.gd
Now try to close **3.gd**.
Current a history hierarchy by:
1.gd -> 2.gd -> 1.gd
We are here ___**^**
Godot editor has highlight 1.gd, but open **2.gd.**
![close_script_bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1049442/25026026/773ac0cc-20c6-11e7-8270-c0410ce5c86f.gif)

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

This is a really minor change. I just changed the link to the IRC channel login from using http to using https.

Thank you for making such a cool game engine! ^ _ ^

data.title: [2.1.3] Massive meshes when I switch OSes
data.body:
Linux Mint 18 -> Windows 10 , Godot 2.1.3

Shortly after 2.1.3 dropped, I decided to try out my game on my Windows partition (I develop on the Linux side, generally)
I updated to 2.1.3, and cloned my repo.
Upon loading my game in the editor, and running it, something very bizarre happened. Several of the meshes, mainly mountains and hills, were now about 100 times larger than they should be. I'm talking like, hill-sized changing to Mount Everest size, escaping my extremely liberal draw distance.
Many of the other meshes and the main groundplane were completely unaffected.
When I switched back to the Linux side and gave it another run, everything was back to normal.
I cannot say whether or not this was present in 2.1.2 as well, as I didn't try it before the update.
My dev partner runs it on Windows 7 and the issue did not occur, so it's possible it might be specific to Windows 10.
Anyone experience anything similar?
Cheers!

data.title: Visual shader node editor to come back?
data.body:
In my first little round of testing with Godot 3, I noticed that we were back to more complex shaders being done by way of scripting only with no node-based shader builder like in Godot 2.1.

Is the Visual Shader Editor slated to come back, I find it very useful for cases like creating a terrain shader (with multiple textures) and other things such as using a colored black and white texture (which allows one to save space since they can have an unlimited combination of colors for use in many different materials)? There's also the whole thing of allowing a lot of different textures for additional detail.

That node-based workflow might work even better now with the improvements made for the visual logic editing, any chance that the VSE will be back in 3.0 final?

data.title: Reference deletion could cause a stack overflow
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0 alpha

**Issue description:**
I've been having weird crashed, I've debugged it and it seems that if you have
a lot of nested objects when to root object is deleted everything is deleted
recursively and this causes a stack overflow

**Steps to reproduce:**
simple script to reproduce a crash
```gdscript
extends Node2D

class Obj:
	var lst = []
	func foo():
		pass

func _ready():
	var root = Obj.new()
	var a
	var b = root
	for i in 1000:
		a = b
		b = Obj.new()
		a.lst.push_back(b)

	print(root)
```

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Ported move_and_slide to KinematicBody (3D)
data.body:
move_and_slide is rather useful for FPS character-controllers, etc - it reduces the amount of boilerplate code.
(It's also a bit inconsistent that it doesn't exist in the 3D scene.)

It might be nice to figure out a way to share the code between the two move_and_slide implementations, but that's for someone who knows what the policy is on shared code like that.

(EDIT: I've attached a test project, which includes both a 3D scene and a basic 2D scene for comparison. This is 1. for some basic testing, and 2. so that if/when the inevitable "why does is_ceiling get set when is_wall is meant" bug report comes, there is something that ought to be extendable into a testbed, as it is consistent between 2D and 3D, through rather wrong behavior as far as I can tell. It could be user error on my part, though if it was, then why does it detect floors as floors?)

(EDIT2: I have a fix for the is_ceiling / is_wall issues in both 2D and 3D, but I'm waiting on this PR to put it into the pipeline since it applies changes to both.)

(EDIT3: On recommendation, I've applied the fix - see #8408 for the 2D version of the fix.)

[ktest.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/920728/ktest.zip)

data.title: Fix FBO depth texture format
data.body:
2D graphics are currently broken in WebGL 2 again, this fixes it.
Also fix inconsistent formatting in the modified file.

data.title: Correct Variant::hash_compare()
data.body:
There was a logic error in #7815 which made
Variant.hash_compare() == Variant.hash_compare() always true.
In an attempt to short-circuit the NaN check I made an (in hindsight) obvious
error: 10 == 12 || is_nan(10) == is_nan(12)

This will be true for all inputs, except for the NaN, not-NaN case. The macro
has been updated to now generate:

(10 == 12) || (is_nan(10) && is_nan(10))

so:

(10 == 12)   || (is_nan(10)  && is_nan(12))  = false
   False  or (False and False) is False
(10 == 10)   || (is_nan(10)  && is_nan(10))  = true
   True or (False and False) is True
(Nan == 10)  || (is_nan(NaN) && is_nan(10))  = false
   False or (True and False) is False
(Nan == Nan) || (is_nan(NaN) && is_nan(NaN)) = true
   False or (True and True) is True

Which is correct for all cases. 

This bug was triggered because the hash function for floating point numbers
can very easily generate collisions for the tested Vector3(). I've also added
an extra hashing step to the float hash function to make this less likely to
occur.

This fixes #8081 and probably many more random weirdness.

data.title: Internal editor should not open when creating connections if external is enabled
data.body:
**Ubuntu 16.10 - Godot version: 2.1.2**


**Issue description:**
Setting an external code editor and creating a signal connection with function using the Node panel, opens the internal code editor and adds the created function there, then appears the external editor, without function added (of course).

I think that the connection creation should not open the internal editor if an external editor is active, even if than means no new function added.

**Steps to reproduce:**
 - Set up an external editor in editor settings.
 - Create a connection to a node with a script with "make function" enabled.
 - Both editors should open, the internal with the function, the external without it.

data.title: Fix gles3-particles shader not compiling
data.body:
Fix for [#8381](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/8381)

Use length(vec3) instead of vec3.length (ARB_shading_language_420pack)
Renamed variable active to shader_active, since the shader didn't compile (reserved keyword)

data.title: FileSystem browser not returning actual file structure
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Debian Linux 9.0, Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
The FileSystem browser gave me an incorrect tree structure. The actual structure is:

- res://
    - Scenes
    - Scripts

Where the structure it returned was  
- res://
    - Scenes
        - Scenes
        - Scripts
    - Scripts
        - Scenes
        - Scripts

**Steps to reproduce:**
As far as I can tell, this can be reproduced by adding a new folder inside of a project folder, then expanding the folder in the FileSystem browser.

data.title: Bug: when spatial_editor-camera-origin rests on worlds y-axis
Some 2D drawing specific methods I'm missing
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0 master

**Issue description:**
Can someone tell me if we already have the following helper functions? They're super useful for UI drawing and save a lot of duplicate code. If not, can I implement them, and if yes, is there a favorized place for such?
- Inflating / deflating `Rect2` structures. If you have a margin (4,4,4,4) and a rect (0,0,100,100), calling `inflate(4,4,4,4)` extends it to (-4,-4,104,104). You can also pass negative numbers to deflate. Idea stolen from .NET `System.Drawing.Rectangle`. Useful for expand margins etc.
- Font drawing is given a `Point2`, but the origin of the resulting text always seems to be bottom-left. Add parameters to `font->draw` to accept center- or right-aligning, also vertically. Needed this quite some time when centering text in rectangles (text in `WindowDialog` titlebar or on tabs), especially since the font ascents and descents are annoying to work with. S. [here](https://github.com/Syroot/XRay/blob/master/src/Syroot.XRay/Video/Font.cs#L154) for some implementation idea in C# (which also fits text into a rectangle).
- "right" and "bottom" properties on Rect2, which basically just return `pos.x + size.x ` or `pos.y + size.y`.

data.title: Godot 3, Creating a particles node leads to console error spam
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win10 64 bit; Ivy Bridge i7 CPU; ATI 77xx GPU with 2017 Crimson ReLive drivers

**Issue description:**
I add a particles node to an empty scene using a Godot 3 build, adding the required material and mesh instance does nothing (ie. no particles are produced like in the .gif images in the news feed) while the console spams error messages at a torrid pace (only stopping if I delete the node or disable its visibility).

**Steps to reproduce:**
Fire up an empty project in Godot 3 and add a particles node, the errors should already start to flow. Try anything, but don't expect anything to work. There's at least 3 unique errors when you delete the node and check the console.

**Link to minimal example project:**
Not needed, it should be fairly easy to do from scratch.

data.title: Setting up a zoomed-out minimap is surprisingly difficult
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1.2

I tried to make a simple example on how to make a minimap that shows a zoomed-out view of the world.
The split-screen example shows the required setup, which works well for split-screen.
However setting up a minimap using this technique is harder because:

It requires two active cameras to live under the same player node. Only one of them can be made current: clicking on both will disable the other one, and vice versa. Not sure how it affects the result, but it's a bit confusing in that situation.

Viewports also don't seem to bother about the project's stretch mode, because when I resize the window the field of view changes instead of stretching and staying centered on the player.

The minimap camera in fact does work, but due to the above, it also renders starting from its virtual top-left corner at 1:1 scale, clamping the rest. As a result, the tiny rectangle shows nothing, or a small part of the background. How can I make it so the center of what the camera sees matches the center of its viewport, and stretch the height to fit while keeping aspect?
Did this change in 3.0?

Project:
[ViewportZoom.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/917824/ViewportZoom.zip)

(I also reproduced https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/1840 on the way, but fix is for 3.0)

data.title: re-enabled obj import
Feature Request: Change default path on project manager
data.body:
It would be better if the default path when searching for projects or creating new ones was the home dir (linux and mac: /home/<user> Windows: c:/Users/<user> [not sure about windows and mac])

In linux (at least) the default path is the path where godot binary is

data.title: Thumbnails not visible in filesystem dock
data.body: Unless it's hidden behind a new editor setting, thumbnails (including image thumbnails) aren't visible in filesystem dock in the current master (which were [apparently](8355) there in 2.1).
